text:
***

 

“No.”

It’s a fair response.

“And you found him because…?”

An even better response. Hawks isn’t in the mood to answer it though; nor does he have one that won’t compromise the state of his mission so instead he shrugs and says, “I heard a cry; I was first on scene.”

Naomasa nods and everyone else buys the tale - which is relief because how Hawks was going to explain trudging through back alleys with a villain, he doesn’t know. There’s a mixed bunch of people in the room - Naomasa, Sansa, Toshinori, Aizawa, Yamada - but they’re all looking at one thing only. Specifically, the A-Rank villain known as Dabi who is, for all intents and purposes, currently five years old.

Hawks is supposed to not know what it happened but he does. A simple accident, a young girl with a quirk she couldn’t control, and suddenly they’re here.

Here could be worse, Hawks reasons. At least, at five years of age, Dabi hasn’t tried to murder him yet. Well, to be honest, that probably comes down to the fact that once the quirk had taken effect, Dabi had seemingly lost all memory up until that point and his mental age seems to have regressed as well. He’d come with Hawks only after he’d flashed his hero license and was confident they were going to the police. He’d fallen asleep on the way over which leads them to where they are now: Dabi asleep on Detective Naomasa’s office couch.

The change is startling, Hawks knows. He can see it on everyone’s faces too. The scars are gone, and with it the accompanying staples. Dabi’s tiny for his age, barely reaching even Hawks’ waist. There are no piercings on his face but perhaps his most defining feature is his red hair. It’s such a difference from the usual black.

“What are we going to do with him?” Toshinori asks, coming to crouch beside the sofa and watching Dabi as he sleeps on.

“We’ll have to question him, of course,” Naomasa sighs, running a hand through his hair. “But besides from that…” His gaze flicks to Aizawa. “You have experience with this sort of-”

“No.” Aizawa’s voice is painfully firm. “This isn’t like Shinsou or Eri. This is a villain.”

“He’s a child,” Naomasa stresses.

“He tried to kill my husband!” Yamada screeches.

Dabi flinches in his sleep, a frightened whimper escaping and despite his talk, Aizawa’s hand is the first to land on his shoulder, shushing the boy and coaxing him back to sleep. Dabi settles with a deep exhale, slipping under once more.

“I can’t,” Aizawa says quietly and Hawks knows that’s that even without having to look at Naomasa’s face.

“I could try,” Toshinori offers. “Although I’ll admit to having never cared for a child before.”

“Who’s to say you even have to?” Hawks asks, giving one of his wings a shake as it starts to itch. “This quirk could wear off any second. You’re almost better off keeping him here.”

“He’s right,” Sansa agrees, gaze watchful.

No one gets to say anymore there though because it seems Aizawa wasn’t as successful as they’d thought. Dabi stirs and slowly opens his eyes. He blinks at being surrounded before scrambling up. He nearly falls off the couch, Yamada supporting him with a hand.

“Easy there, little listener. You’re alright, you’re with the police.”

Naomasa hands over his badge, Dabi rolling it over in his tiny hands before giving it back. His voice, when he speaks, is so, so quiet. It’s barely above a whisper and Hawks feels his heart break because somehow he can tell that this is his regular volume. “Am I going home now? Did you call my mother?”

“Not yet,” Naomasa says gently, taking a seat on the coffee table as Toshinori backs away.

To their shock, Dabi’s eyes fly to the window before widening. “I have to go!” he says suddenly, trying to get to his feet only to be sat back down by Aizawa. “P-please! I have to go!”

“Go where?” Aizawa drawls.

“Home,” he stammers, squirming harder. “If I’m not home before dark then Mother will get in trouble and Father will...will…” Dabi can’t seem to continue, dissolving into tears.

Aizawa hisses and all his words are suddenly out the window. He’s rounding the couch faster than even Hawks could, drawing Dabi to his chest and smoothing his hair down. “It’s fine kid. They know, okay? They know you’re here.”

Dabi pauses, pulling away with a sniff. “Father too?” Aizawa nods, Dabi shying away. “Was he...angry?”

There’s a pause before Naomasa answers. “He...understood.”

Dabi’s expression flattens. “Father doesn’t…” He then stares at his lap glumly. “Of course; you’re the police. Father can’t be angry at you.”

“Wherever your father is, I’m sure he isn’t angry,” Toshinori tries.

Dabi snorts, and it’s the first time Hawks sees him looking like his future self. “Father’s always angry,” he spits. “That’s why he hits us. That’s why he hurts Mother. That’s why she cries all the time.”

Hawks winces, as do a few others in the room. Naomasa suddenly has a pen and paper in his hands, leaning forward ever so slightly. “What’s your father’s name?”

“Naomasa,” Aizawa warns quietly. “Don’t. You can’t stop this.”

The detective swears but Hawks knows Aizawa’s right. All of this happened a long time ago. They can’t stop it now. Dabi looks between them in confusion but he never answers the question. Interesting. Hawks gives him a nudge but Dabi shakes his head furiously. Somehow though, the switch has been flipped and from that point on, Dabi won’t talk to them at all. Clearly he’s more terrified of his father than he is of them.

“I hate this,” Aizawa says once they’ve left the room and Dabi is alone with Sansa, drawing with some pencils they found in a storeroom. “I don’t want…”

Yamada pulls him into his arms. “You don’t want to feel sorry for him. I get it Shouta.”

“Life gets rough for the kid,” Hawks sighs, peering in the window. “I mean, I don’t feel like I’m looking at a villain right now.”

“No one is born a villain,” Toshinori says, and there’s something painful in there that Hawks doesn’t understand. “They’re made them by circumstances. I only wish we could stop those circumstances sooner. Not just for Dabi, but for all villains.”

“You’ve been the number one hero for too long,” Aizawa grouses, removing himself from Yamada’s embrace. “You can’t save everyone.”

Toshinori glares at him but Naomasa comes between them, shaking his head. “This is no place for such an argument. And really, you two shouldn’t be having it at all. You’re adults and heroes for your own reasons. Keep it that way.”

Toshinori looks suitably scolded, Aizawa merely defensive. Before anything else can be said though, Sansa is gesturing through the window silently and that’s enough to grab their attention. It’s for good reason too because Dabi has since shifted and is leaning over the table to draw. Which gives them a wonderful view of his back...and the plethora of bruises that cover it. He may have been changed into clothes roughly his size, but shirts ride up and what was hidden underneath this one is enough to make Hawks’ stomach turn.

“I didn’t do that to him on the way over,” is the first thing he says.

“I’m sure not,” Naomasa murmurs even as Toshinori goes pale and Aizawa’s jaw clenches.

“If his father did that to him,” Aizawa hisses, Yamada placing a hand on his arm even as he’s on the phone. Hawks wonders who he’s calling but Yamada answers that himself soon enough.

“Recovery Girl’s on her way. If nothing else, she can make him feel a little better.”

There’s nothing they can do except wait for Chiyo to arrive. She bustles her way in a good half an hour later. Dabi has since grown bored of drawing but is still locked in the detective’s office - not that he knows it. He’s taken to asking Sansa about his quirk or at least, the cat related aspects of it. The first thing Chiyo does is dismiss Sansa before ushering Dabi back onto the sofa he’d occupied previously. Dabi’s apprehensive, that much is obvious, but it’s obvious Chiyo has done this before.

“I’ve been asked to check over you,” she says, placing a hand on his knee. “My name’s Chiyo. My quirk can heal people.”

Dabi’s interest is gained there, feet swinging. “Can you heal everything?”

“Most things,” Chiyo replies with a hum, going through the whole rigmarole of checking his reflexes and shining lights in his eyes. “And what about you? Do you have a quirk?”

Dabi freezes. Chiyo doesn’t push him though and eventually he whispers, “I have one. I don’t use it though. It hurts people. I don’t want to hurt people.”

Chiyo frowns, as do Aizawa and Naomasa. “Quirks don’t hurt people unless we want them to,” she scolds. “And if you don’t use it, how will you learn to control it?”

“If I don’t use it, I don’t need to control it,” Dabi argues back, though his shoulders are hunched over, showing how unconfident he really is.

“I see,” is all Chiyo says. “I can’t help but notice your shoulders look stiff. Does your back hurt?”

Dabi reels back, shaking his head furiously. One look from Chiyo has him wilting though. With great, great reluctance he turns around, lifting his shirt. Hawks’ stomach drops to the floor and Aizawa swears. Because Dabi looks terrible. His skin is mottled because of how extensive the marks are and, with a shiver, Hawks notes how similar he looks to his adult state.

“This looks bad,” Chiyo tuts, looking but not touching. “Can you tell me what happened?”

“It’s nothing,” Dabi murmurs, tugging his shirt back down and wrapping his arms around his chest vulnerably. “It’s just training. I...Father says I have a good quirk. That I...I can be better than All Might and I...I need to train. It’s just training,” he repeats hoarsely. “Training to be the best.”

There’s a sob from his left, Hawks’ eyes flying over to see Toshinori hiding his face in a hand as his shoulders shake. “That isn’t…” he chokes on his next words. “I...That isn’t what being the number one hero is about. To do that...to your child…”

The once Symbol of Peace breaks down further, Naomasa sighing and rubbing his back soothingly. “This isn’t your fault,” he murmurs but all Toshinori does is shake his head. Hawks agrees.

Their attention is ripped away though when Chiyo flips open a file, tapping at something at the top. “Oh dear, look at this. They didn’t even write your name down! How silly.”

Dabi giggles there. The villain fucking giggles.

But then the weight of that sentence slams into them all. Because no one knows Dabi’s identity. They hadn’t, in all honesty, even thought to ask. If Hawks had to guess, it’s because they all simply assumed Dabi was Dabi. They hadn’t thought to look at that deeper level.

“Touya,” Dabi supplies - or Touya, Hawks supposes, although that feels wrong.

“Touya,” Chiyo parrots, writing that down. “What a lovely name.”

Dabi blushes and dammit, villains aren’t meant to be cute, even in child form! Hawks pushes that thought aside even as Naomasa is hastily scribbling down the name. He knows that before the day is out, Dabi’s real identity will be known by everyone in the hero community.

“And here?” Chiyo asks, indicating a different empty box; Touya’s family name, if Hawks had to guess.

Dabi leans over to see better, all too chipper when he answers. “Todoroki!”

The whole room stills. It’s like the air gets sucked out of the office. Hawks thinks every inch of body heat has left him. Toshinori is paler than Hawks has ever seen, while Aizawa looks ready to murder. Even Recovery Girl looks thrown, so much so that Dabi’s head cocks to the side, all five-year-old innocence.

“Do you want me to write it?” he asks, all politeness. “I can!”

He takes the pen and writes the kanji and even as slow and wobbling as he is, Hawks knows what Dabi’s writing. He isn’t lying. Todoroki Touya, aka Dabi. It’s at this point Chiyo regains her wits even if Dabi seems bored now, comfortable enough around her to climb all over the couch. Complimenting him, it seems, did wonders.

“Can you tell me who’s in your family?” Chiyo asks, just to dig the hole deeper, to confirm what they already know.

Dabi shrugs and nods all at the same time. “There’s Father and Mother. Father has a fire quirk and I don’t like him. Mother has an ice quirk but she’s nice.” He grins there before bouncing up and down a few times. “And there’s Fuyumi; she’s three, I’m five! And Natsuo too but he’s only a baby. I don’t know his quirk yet. But we don’t have the perfect quirk,” Dabi babbles on. “Father says even though I’m strong, I can’t really beat All Might so Mother has to have more babies.”

Toshinori drops into a chair then and Hawks would have thought he’d fainted if not for the fact that his eyes are very much open and tears are streaming down his cheeks.

“And so he makes Shouto,” Aizawa growls, Yamada grabbing him before he can punch something. “Like his wife and children are nothing more than mere tools.”

Hawks can’t wrap his head around the concept itself. Even as more and more of Dabi’s traits and frivolous throw away lines start to fall into place, Hawks still struggles to believe it because it’s Endeavour. And Endeavour is everything he’s ever wanted to be but he can’t be if he’s like this.

Naomasa stopped writing long ago. He looks like he doesn’t know what to do. Hawks doesn’t blame him.

“-nd here, I’m on a rainbow,” Dabi is explaining to Chiyo, pointing at his drawing like he hasn’t just potentially torn the station and the current hero rankings apart.

“And where are you going?” Chiyo prods, barely holding herself together from what Hawks can tell.

“Away,” is all Dabi says, Hawks swearing.

Chiyo ruffles his hair, handing him some gummies. “Well, you seem alright to me now Touya. I’ll show the detective back in, alright?”

Dabi shrugs, unconcerned. Chiyo makes it as far as the door before turning around, asking one last question. “When you grow up young Touya, what do you want to be? What do you want to do?”

“What do I want to do?” Dabi repeats. He frowns for a moment before grinning and it looks so, so wrong. “When I grow up, I’m going to kill my father.”

 

***





***

 

“I’ll take him.”

Everyone whips around even as Yamada is stammering incomprehensibly. “Sh-Shouta, you can’t! He’s-”

“A villain?” Aizawa asks before shaking his head, eyes turning to the room Dabi is in, pushing a toy truck across the coffee table. “Naomasa was right. This is a child. A scared one.”

“Aizawa,” Naomasa warns. “We don’t know when this quirk will wear off. It’s safest to keep him here. It’s what’s best.”

“My quick can stop his,” he returns quickly enough. “And do you honestly believe that? Do you think you should keep a five-year-old here? Would you put him in a cell?”

“Aizawa, that’s enough,” Toshinori says but Naomasa stops him with a hand, sighing.

“No, he’s right. What we’re dealing with now is not Dabi, but Touya. The real best thing for him would be to return him to his family but…” Naomasa cringes. “With what he’s said, I can’t. In no way can I justify putting him into that situation.”

The agreements are unanimous and Hawks has to make an excuse just so he can leave the room. The thoughts whirling through his head are too much and it feels like Dabi’s presence is looming over him. “I’ll head back to where I found him and see if there were any cameras nearby. The more we know about this quirk, the better.”

Naomasa nods thankfully and Hawks takes his leave. Naomasa then shoots Toshinori a look and he reluctantly bids farewell as well. Everyone in the room knows his shoulders are weighed down with more than just pain and age old weariness now. This afternoon has taken its toll on the once Symbol of Peace. Some ugly things have come out and everyone has their own way of dealing. Whether it’s good or not is another question all together.

“Are you sure?” Naomasa asks, one last time.

Aizawa glances at Yamada who gives a helpless shrug before nodding. “We’re sure.”

 

***

 

If Aizawa had had any second guesses about Touya not being a real five-year-old, they’re dashed the moment Naomasa takes Touya aside and explains to him the truth of his situation. He can’t understand it - he’s actually twenty-four? He doesn’t live at home? He can’t see his family? It’s too much for a child and while he comes with Aizawa and Yamada, he cries all the way to their apartment. Not great heaving sobs but quiet sniffles, like he knows crying won’t get him any results but he’s too upset to hold it in. Aizawa pities him, scooping the kid up as soon as they park and tucking him into his neck.

“Come on, let’s get inside.”

Touya nods but a whimper still escapes. “I want Mother.”

It’s all he’s asked for and it’s the one thing that’s impossible. Aizawa doesn’t know the details but he knows one simple truth: Todoroki Rei lives in the mental ward of a hospital. Touya absolutely cannot stay with her.

Dinner is a quiet affair. Yamada tries to lighten the mood and while he gets a smile or two, he never gets a laugh. Touya showers when told to and comes back in an old shirt they’d found; it comes past his knees for how short he is. Aizawa bundles him up and tucks him into what was once Shinsou’s bed. He leaves the door open a crack and tells Touya to find them if he needs anything. Touya hesitates before catching his sleeve, eyes brimming with tears once more.

“I was good,” he whispers, wiping his eyes with his spare hand. “I ate all my dinner and even the vegetables. I wasn’t loud and I didn’t make a mess. I was good,” he repeats brokenly. “Can I...Can I see Mother now? Am I not in trouble anymore?”

Yamada swears from where he’s eavesdropping and Aizawa is dropping into a crouch at the same moment, brushing Touya’s hair back. “You aren’t in trouble kid. You never were. This is just...a quirk.”

He doesn’t understand. “But…”

Aizawa knows he’s going to regret this but it can’t hurt. “Sleep tonight and we’ll see your mother in the morning, alright?”

Touya’s eyes widen before he nods quickly. He scrubs his face messily and then burrows under the blankets. He isn’t asleep by any means but there’s nothing more Aizawa can do. He murmurs a quiet goodnight before leaving the room. Yamada smiles at him weakly and Aizawa just drops onto the sofa. He’d forgotten how hard this was.

He goes to sleep a couple of hours later to the sound of hiccuping sobs coming from the bedroom down the hall.

 

***

 

The morning goes a little better. Touya is a tad more talkative and smiles a little more but he’s also antsy. He wants to go, that much is obvious. Aizawa has to pull him up multiple times and warn him that he’s not staying with his mother, just visiting. Touya nods but Aizawa knows he doesn’t believe him. This afternoon is not going to be fun; not at all.

But that’s later’s problem and Aizawa is now walking through the hospital corridors looking for Todoroki Rei’s room. Touya is silent at his side, overwhelmed by the hustle and bustle going on around them. He’s back in the clothes he’d worn yesterday, freshly washed and crisp. He’s on his absolute best behaviour and Aizawa cannot even fathom how this sweet child becomes everything Dabi is. Unfortunately, Touya can’t give him any answers. He, if anything, would only be more clueless.

Rapping on the door labelled ‘Todoroki’, Aizawa’s met with a call to enter. Touya perks up, recognising the voice. He wrenches open the door before Aizawa can ask him to wait.

“Mother!”

The precise moment he does so is the precise moment Aizawa realises he should have done more research. Even as he’s reaching for Touya to haul him back, Todoroki Rei is screaming, lashing out and only missing Touya because Aizawa grabs him.

“M-Mother?” Touya asks, shaking violently.

“You’re not...you’re…” Rei is deathly pale and shaking almost as severely. “Take him away,” she begs.

Aizawa scoops Touya up with a nod, grunting as the boy flails in his arms. “Touya, stop.”

“No, but Mother!” Touya wails, trying to scramble over his shoulder. “Mother please, it’s me! Mother, it’s Touya! Mother!”

Aizawa shushes him quite sternly as the elevator opens and Touya does but probably only because he’s sobbing into his shoulder. Aizawa sighs, chest heavy with guilt. “I’m sorry,” he murmurs, rubbing Touya’s back. “I didn’t know she would do that.”

“What did I do?” Touya sobs. “Is it because I didn’t come home? You said you told Father!”

“This isn’t because of that,” Aizawa grunts but Touya just kicks him petulantly.

The elevator deposits them on the ground floor and Aizawa is fully intending to leave when he hears his name being called. Oh god, he recognises that voice. Turning around, Aizawa thinks the situation can’t get any worse until he sees that the owner of the voice is not alone. It’s worse. Because there, standing barely three feet away, are Midoriya Izuku and Toshinori. Of course they are.

“Mr. Aizawa?” Izuku questions, stepping closer to get a look at the boy in his arms. “Oh, hello. Are you alright?”

Touya eyes up Midoriya for a moment before shaking his head. Midoriya grimaces before peering up at Aizawa curiously. Aizawa knows what that look’s asking but he ignores it, preferring to turn the tables. “What are you doing here Midoriya?”

“Ah, I’m seeing a physical therapist!” he pipes up brightly, holding out his mangled hand. “There’s still some stiffness so I’m working to get full movement back!”

Aizawa gives a satisfied nod before lifting his gaze. “And you?”

Toshinori spreads his hands helplessly. “I’m afraid I’m a rather frequent visitor around these parts. But luckily I had young Midoriya join me today!”

Midoriya beams like Toshinori’s just hung the stars for him, Aizawa mentally rolling his eyes. But then he gets caught because he’s out of questions to hide behind, Midoriya hesitantly smiling at Touya again. “And this is...?”

Aizawa could not answer but with Midoriya, that would probably only make it worse. Instead he levels the student with a glare. “Midoriya, what I’m about to tell you cannot leave this hospital, do you understand?”

Midoriya’s expression turns frightfully serious, something Aizawa has rarely seen him do. “I understand.”

Aizawa eyes him up before nodding, coaxing Touya’s head up. “This is Todoroki Touya. Yesterday he was hit by a quirk that de-aged him some nineteen years.”

Midoriya’s eyes widen. “Todoroki’s...older brother?”

Touya blinks, frowning. “Todo-...you know Natsuo?”

“Natsuo?” Midoriya repeats, shaking his head. “No, I-...” Midoriya hastily cuts off, a hand clapping over his mouth. The damage is already done though.

Aizawa draws Touya up to eye level. “Midoriya here goes to class with your little brother, Shouto. You haven’t met him yet.”

“Sh...Shouto…” Touya murmurs, rolling the name over his tongue. “He...is he littler than Natsuo?”

“Yes.”

“I have a photo!” Midoriya offers, fossicking through his pocket until he finds his phone. He then goes frightfully still, breath catching. “You’re...Aizawa, how old is Touya?”

“I’m five!” Touya cuts in before Aizawa can, folding his arms and pouting, clearly offended Midoriya thought he didn’t know.

If anything, Midoriya goes paler. Over his head, Aizawa and Toshinori exchange looks. “Midoriya.” Aizawa’s voice is painfully stern and makes the boy cower. “What?”

Midoriya shakes his head quickly. “Todoroki wouldn’t want me to say.”

Aizawa raises an eyebrow coolly. “I got an earful from Touya yesterday. If I find you’re keeping something potentially dangerous a secret, you’ll be in trouble with someone far more frightening than Todoroki.”

Midoriya squeaks and Toshinori tries to defend him but Aizawa won’t have it. Eventually Midoriya folds, hands wringing together nervously. “Uh...that is...Todoroki said when he was five, his, uh...his mother…” Midoriya gestures loosely at where Aizawa knows Todoroki’s scar is. “Because he...he looked like…”

Aizawa holds up a hand there, not wanting Touya to hear too many gruesome details. Besides, it’s not like he and Toshinori don’t know what Midoriya was going to say anyway:

Todoroki Rei burnt Shouto for looking like Endeavour.

Looking at the boy in his arms, Aizawa swears. Touya, if anything, looks more like Enji. It’s no wonder she panicked upon seeing him.

“Young Midoriya, why didn’t you tell anyone?” Toshinori asks gently.

Midoriya shrugs. “I...Why didn’t Todoroki?”

Aizawa lets it slide, waving Toshinori away. It still hasn’t solved the problem of what he’s going to do with Touya now. He may have swapped to snivelling but Aizawa’s sure he’s just minutes away from another bout of tears. Midoriya seems to realise this, awkwardly holding out a hand. “There are some beautiful gardens here Touya, with animals made of trees. Would you like to see?”

Touya hesitates, leaning forward only to snap back and hide against Aizawa’s chest somewhat. “Are you...a hero?”

Midoriya blinks twice before nodding, reaching into his wallet and pulling out his provisional hero license and handing it over. “I’m going to be a hero just like All Might!”

Toshinori abruptly hacks into his hand but Touya doesn’t notice, just smiles the tiniest bit. “Yeah, he seems nice,” he whispers, handing the license back and pushing at Aizawa to indicate he wants down.

Aizawa does so and Midoriya takes Touya’s hand, leading him out the southern door of reception. Aizawa follows, Toshinori on his heels. The gardens prove to be a good distraction and Midoriya is a surprisingly good babysitter. For all his jittering and incessant ramblings, he’s actually calm and soft around Touya. It’s like he’s found Touya’s volume level and is keeping them on the same page. According to Toshinori, he’s exactly like Midoriya Inko. Aizawa doesn’t question how he knows that and let’s the old hero go and join his protege.

“Excuse me?”

Aizawa turns at the voice, having to beat down the surprise he feels. “I’m sorry for the trouble we caused earlier.”

Todoroki Rei shakes her head. “That...I’m afraid that was on me.” She steps to Aizawa’s side, glancing down at where Midoriya and Touya are. “I...When you left, you called him Touya. Was I mistaken?”

Aizawa shakes his head. “He was hit with a quirk yesterday. He has no memories from any time after age five.”

Rei’s eyes widen. “He...he said he was five?” Aizawa nods. “Oh. Then he...Natsuo would have just been born. He doesn’t know Shouto yet, or...or why I’m here.”

“No,” Aizawa agrees. “And I apologise for bringing him to see you without warning. Had I known his presence would have been upsetting, we wouldn’t have come.”

Rei shakes her head. “I...panicked. He reminded me so much of Shouto, of their father, and it took me back. All I could hear was Shouto crying. But…” Her hands clench into fists. “This is Touya. Am I...am I allowed to see him?”

Aizawa grimaces. “Is that best for him?”

Rei hesitates before nodding. “Yes. He needs me to tell him I’m sorry.” With that, she cups her hands around her mouth. “Touya!”

Not long after Aizawa calls them to breakfast. And as Touya happily munches away, eating foods Aizawa now knows are his favourites, Aizawa only feels worse and worse. He’s leading a lamb to the slaughter.

And, worst of all, he’s supposed to be okay with it.

They arrive at the station just after midday. Toshinori is already there, having been in meetings with Naomasa all morning. Aizawa doesn’t know what the pair talk about, but he knows they’re often together. There’s things they know that he doesn’t and, as time progresses, Aizawa is starting to think more and more that one of those things involves Midoriya. A hand curls around his, Aizawa snarling, already knowing who it is. “We actually don’t,” Toshinori whispers. “I made some calls, used my position. The commission was very...unforthcoming regarding this.”

“You think it’s a job,” Yamada surmises.

Toshinori nods. “I think...Hawks is in a delicate situation right now.”

Aizawa snorts. “Commission or not, I’m sure he’s gone above and beyond in some aspects.”

He doesn’t need to specify which areas and Toshinori goes red to the tips of his ears. Naomasa also coughs awkwardly while Yamada simply looks ill. They don’t get to dwell on it though - although it does explain Hawks’ absence - because at that moment the doors to the police station open. The doors opening isn’t what gets their attention, but rather the heat wave that follows it and Aizawa already knows that what means, eyes flying to Touya. Touya, to his credit, already knows as well. He swallows thickly and gets to his feet, head bowed. It’s a submissive pose if Aizawa has ever seen one.

Aizawa understands but that doesn’t make it okay, taking two steps closer to the boy even as Endeavour glares at him. Aizawa wonders how he even found them. Who did he pressure? Who finally caved?

“Ah, Enji!” Toshinori greets grandly and Aizawa is, for once, grateful for his overzealousness. “It’s good to see-”

“You, quiet.”

The tone is deathly cold and Aizawa does a double take as Toshinori pales. He pulls himself back up seconds later but it’s already too late, he’s already shown that fatal weakness. Endeavour eyes them all up as though they’re nothing more than minor inconveniences.

“I’ll be taking my son.”

It’s a statement.

“I’m afraid I can’t allow that,” Naomasa intervenes. “Touya is currently part of a police investigation.”

“Is he facing charges?” Endeavour sneers, knowing the answer. He nods when Naomasa doesn’t answer. “Then he comes with me.”

“Enji,” Toshinori tries again and Aizawa has to admit, credit where credit’s due. “This is a...delicate time. This quirk will wear off soon and it would be safer for Touya to be here when it happened than-”

“Toshinori.” Said man’s jaw snaps shut. “Are you insinuating I can’t control my own child?”

Unfortunately, it’s the exact opposite. He can control Touya and that, ironically, is what they’re all trying to prevent. Because they’ve seen Endeavour’s method of ‘control’ and no one deserves to go through that.

Aizawa’s tempted to let Endeavour take him purely so Touya can light him on fire sometime very soon but he’s pretty sure that’s frowned upon. Also, it creates all sorts of hassles on their end, especially considering none of them have actually filed that they have an actual live villain in their midst that they’re all protecting and, even worse, sending on outings. Aizawa doubts the press would be impressed to discover they’d had a villain in custody for five days and they let him play video games and go for ice-cream. And so, he has to step in.

“Naomasa has already said no,” he drawls. “As a police officer, his jurisdiction goes above yours.”

And it does, in the law system. However, Endeavour seems to know the system as well as Aizawa does.

“When acting as a hero, yes,” Endeavour says all too smugly. “As a father, no. Touya, now.”

Before any of them can push back, Aizawa feels a hand grasp his own momentarily. The next second Touya is at Endeavour’s side, turning to them and bowing shortly. “I’m sorry, for the trouble I’ve caused.”

“As you should be,” Endeavour snaps down at him, Touya flinching. His hand, when it lands on his son’s shoulders, looks near painful. “We’re leaving.”

“...yes sir.”

Toshinori makes an aborted motion but he doesn’t have to finish it because as Endeavour has contacts, clearly Hawks does too. Aizawa feels his emotions conflict at the sight of the winged hero but he barely spares them a glance, feigning obliviousness as he bumps into Endeavour and then smiles widely.

“Hey, hey, imagine seeing you here!” he crows, arms spreading wide. “And who’s this? You never said you had a kid smaller than Shouto!”

“I don’t,” Endeavour grinds out, trying to push past only to fail. “This is my eldest.”

Hawks looks at Endeavour like he’s an idiot. “Uh...kinda short, don’t you think?”

Bets are off, Aizawa likes him again. Touya giggles and Hawks flinches when Endeavour’s fingers dig into his shoulder sharply, warning clear. “This is a quirk, obviously. I’m taking him home.”

“Oh cool,” Hawks sings, falling in step like it’s second nature. “I’ll come with! You never talk about your family. Now I get to see it in person.”

Endeavour glares at him but Hawks just smiles back serenely. “You are not invited,” Endeavour spits.

“Don’t be like that,” Hawks whines, and they’re dangerously close to leaving the station now. Realistically, letting Touya go so long as Hawks is by his side is better than letting him leave alone but it’s far from ideal. Because, again, they might not get Dabi back, not if Hawks turns a blind eye. “Besides, can’t see you as a kid person anyway. And he’s, what, three?”

“I’m five!” Touya protests and it’s innocent enough but it creates the crack; one pressure too many. Endeavour backhands him and Aizawa can tell it’s a warning - and isn’t that just sick in itself? - but it’s already too much. Aizawa had always known Hawks was fast but he’s never seen him in action until just now. Before he can so much as blink, before Endeavour can pull his hand back, before Touya can cry, Hawks is behind them, said boy in his arms. One wing is flared out, the other curled around Touya protectively, and his eyes are burning.

“Don’t touch him.”

Aizawa’s eyes widen ever so slightly. This isn’t a job to Hawks, he suddenly realises. He isn’t stringing Dabi along. No, there’s feelings there and they’re coming through like beacons now.

Endeavour blinks at him in confusion. “That’s...Hawks, return my son.”

Hawks doesn’t so much as bat an eyelid. “Sorry Enji-” Aizawa takes satisfaction in how the hero reels there, “-but I won’t let Touya get hurt by you again.”

There’s a beat and then suddenly the weight of that sentence seems to hit. There are implications there. Implications that one, Hawks knows what Endeavour’s done behind closed doors and two, he knows Touya because Endeavour hasn’t disclosed Touya’s name to him yet.

“So you were in on it,” Endeavour realises, eyes narrowing.

Hawks doesn’t answer him, just lifts Touya’s chin with a hand. “Hey, you good?”

Touya goes to nod before seemingly remembering something. He then shakes his head and bursts into tears. Hawks tightens his grip, tucks Touya further into his chest. He sends a pleading look at Aizawa and Toshinori and of course, they’re trying to keep Touya away from things that upset him, that overload his emotions.

“I can leave,” he murmurs, so low only Aizawa can hear it. “I can do that before Endeavour can catch me.”

Aizawa peers down at him. “But would you return him?”

He points at Touya by way of explanation and Hawks’ cocks his head in confusion before suddenly all the blood drains from his face. He stumbles back a step, swallowing thickly, but in the exchange they’ve forgotten the most volatile person in the room. And just like that, Endeavour’s hand is wrapped around Hawks’ arm, yanking him forward. There’s the smell of burning, Hawks whimpering as some feathers are obviously caught in the crossfire but it doesn’t make Endeavour relent.

“My son, Hawks.”

Blue.

That’s the only colour Aizawa can see.

And heat. All he can feel is heat.

His vision clears and Aizawa can only dread what he sees:

Todoroki Touya, aka Dabi, standing tall at over six feet, glaring at his father with murder in his eyes while Hawks nurses a burnt wing behind him. Endeavour looks shell shocked.

“You.”

Dabi spares a look over his shoulder at Hawks. He then let his head loll forward, flames wrapping up his arms.

“Payback time.”

So many things happen in that next instant, Aizawa isn’t sure he can catalogue them all. Dabi moves at the same time Hawks does, one going to attack, the other going to block. Endeavour is calling flames to his hand the same second Toshinori - Toshinori, god dammit! - jumps in front of him. Natsuo takes that moment to arrive and it’s just a mess all around. Aizawa barely has time to activate his quirk and render Dabi useless before the two Todorokis collide.

“Stop it!” Hawks hisses. “This isn’t the time!”

Dabi’s eyes narrow at him before flicking to Aizawa. “Let me go.”

It’s a command but Aizawa won’t fall for it. Toshinori is pleading with Endeavour on the other side and perhaps the one thing that makes everyone pause, gives them a second to breathe, is Endeavour knocking Toshinori aside only for Toshinori to somehow summon from deep inside of him enough remnants of his quirk to become All Might. The change startles everyone; All Might may be gone but his form is as intimidating as it always was.

“Enough.”

He doesn’t shout the words but they boom all the same.

Dabi seems about to dismiss him when Hawks says that one word that tilts the whole situation:

“Touya.”

It’s like the air leaves the police station. Dabi whips around to Hawks, eyes wide with what Aizawa can only describe as panic. He’s paler than ever and Natsuo takes that moment to cross the room and wrap a hand around Dabi’s wrist. It’s obvious he knows and Dabi reels at that too.

The whole exchange takes place in less than five seconds and Aizawa needs it to because he’s reaching his limit and Toshinori clearly is too. He then says something he hopes he won’t regret.

“Hawks, get them out of here.”

Hawks, to his credit, doesn’t second guess him at all. He and the two Todorokis are gone seconds later and Endeavour shouts in rage just as Toshinori stumbles back and ends up hacking into his hand as Naomasa supports him. Aizawa doesn’t blink when Endeavour rounds on him.

“You let him escape.”

“I would have thought,” he drawls, “That you’d be more concerned about why your son openly tried to kill you. It’s interesting...what could have driven him to do that.”

Endeavour’s eyes flash. “You know nothing.”

Aizawa scoffs, arms folding. “I know surprisingly a lot. If I were you, I’d let this go. At least, for now.”

He doesn’t think he will, but something in his expression must be enough because Endeavour actually backs down. He’s then storming to the door, phone in hand, and Aizawa has no doubt who he’s ringing. Hopefully, Natsuo will be smart enough not to answer.

They land in a deserted park what is probably only minutes later. Natsuo goes to pull Touya into a hug but the hero Hawks stops him. He’s about to protest when Touya abruptly pushes himself away and is violently ill into the rubbish bin closest. His motion sickness suddenly comes back to Natsuo but it also makes him frown a little because it seems as though Hawks knew about it. And how does Hawks, the number two hero, know that his brother, a high ranked villain, suffers from motion sickness? Something doesn’t add up.

Still, once Touya composes himself, Natsuo passes over a bottle of water, huffing when it’s snatched from his grip. “Not even a thank you?”

His tone is teasing enough but Touya - or maybe it’s Dabi - just sneers at him. The difference from two days ago is startling. “Why should I?”

Hawks groans. “Civility guys, come on.”

All that does though is get Touya’s attention to turn to him and Natsuo yelps when his brother suddenly has a fistful of Hawks’ collar and is yanking him off the ground. “And what was that stunt? Changing sides?”

Hawks merely rolls his eyes. “We were in a police station; my hands were tied. Anyway, don’t you wanna know how you got there?”

There’s too much to unpack there but Natsuo is only concerned with how Touya suddenly looks uncertain, thrown. “I…”

Natsuo shuffles forward, tentatively holding out his phone. It’s open to a photo he’d taken at the festival; one of him and Touya. Touya barely spares the photograph a second of his time before doing a hilarious double take. The phone is snatched up and Natsuo can see him zooming in and scrolling through his camera roll. Luckily he has nothing incriminating on there.

When he’s done, Touya turns straight to Hawks and yeah, that hurts a bit. “What is this?” he demands.

“A quirk,” Hawks supplies with a shrug, grinning breezily when Touya snarls at him. “You make an adorable toddler.”

“Stop teasing him,” Natsuo says quietly, trying again at laying a hand on Touya’s arm. Touya flinches but doesn’t move away, even if his jaw is clenched so hard Natsuo is surprised his teeth don’t shatter. “You were five-years-old again. Your memories were gone too. It was...odd.”

“How long?”

“Five days.”

Touya stiffens. “And you, what, kept me?”

“You’re a villain,” Hawks cuts in, tone icy. “We didn’t have a choice. Plus, you were five. Who lets a five-year-old roam the streets?”

“You weren’t locked up,” Natsuo placates.

Touya snorts in derision. “I’m sure. Because you’d all just let a villain walk around.”

Natsuo wants to hit him. Hawks actually does, though it’s nothing more than a light punch to the stomach. “Pretty sure your brother just showed you pictures of you, you know, outside.”

The third time is, apparently, the charm because it’s the time that finally makes Touya snap. “What do you mean, brother?”

It’s the wrong thing to say, to both of him. Natsuo’s expression flattens while Hawks bristles in anger and this time it’s Hawks dragging Touya down. “You’ve got some nerve Todoroki Touya, making me risk everything for you and your little gang when you were the one holding every card to your chest. “Easy birdi-”

Touya doesn’t get to finish, Hawks doing something Natsuo isn’t fast enough to catch and slamming his brother into the ground. “You talk to him,” he snaps at Natsuo before marching away, shoulders hunched over in what suspiciously looks like hurt.

Natsuo looks back around just in time to see Touya look guilty. The look’s gone as soon as it appears but it’s enough, the pieces sliding together. He sighs. “So you and Hawks, huh?”

Touya stares down at him like he’s the scum of the earth. “So pretentious, Todoroki Natsuo.”

He doesn’t hit him, he doesn’t, but Natsuo’s hand stops just shy of his cheek, shoulders shaking as he tries not to sob. “Stop it, just stop it,” he begs. “You’re not...Touya, please. I know, okay? I know you had it so much worse than the rest of us and I know I didn’t do enough and I should have. I know I failed you as a brother! I looked for you Touya, looked everywhere but you were just gone. So don’t pretend you don’t know me now! You’re better than that!”

Touya takes a subconscious step back. He has that look on his face that says he wasn’t aware he was actually passable at anything, let alone above the bottom line.

“I’m not-”

“None of us are,” Natsuo snaps. “We’re all not what we used to be. How could we be? But you don’t have to make it worse!”

Touya flinches and Natsuo takes that as good enough. He embraces Touya and this time, he isn’t pushed back. The hug isn’t returned by any means but it’s more than Natsuo expected. He lets go sooner than he’d like but his smile remains a little longer. When it’s time to talk though, Natsuo steps away. He nods in Hawks’ direction.

“They,” - meaning the heroes, “-refused to let Father near you. They’ve been hiding you, keeping you safe. I think Hawks risked a lot.”

Touya stuffs his hands into his pockets. “I didn’t ask him too.”

Natsuo smiles sadly. “Sometimes, you don’t have to.”

Touya doesn’t reply, just stalks over to where Hawks is. Hawks looks unimpressed and honestly, Natsuo doesn’t blame him. As the pair start talking, Natsuo fiddles with his phone. He’s unsurprised at the amount of missed calls that stare back at him, all from the same person. He keeps his phone on ‘do not disturb’ and flicks a text Shouto’s way to tell him to steer clear too. He gets a thumbs up back almost straight away which makes it clear their father’s obviously been harrassing Shouto too. Typical.

Natsuo looks up at a noise up ahead, which turns out to be Hawks knocking Touya’s hand away with a wing. Touya looks indignant while the hero looks betrayed and that’s worse than him being angry in Natsuo’s mind. Anger is easy to soothe. Broken trust? That’s near impossible to repair.

The pair come back over, Hawks looking anywhere but at Touya. “I’m supposed to be on duty,” he mumbles. “And, I mean, I’ll probably lose my job over this but I’m leaving him with you. You do what you think is best.”

Natsuo’s mouth drops open, Touya’s too, but then Hawks is gone. All that’s left of him is a message appearing on Natsuo’s phone and how did Hawks even get his number?

Either way, he stomps on Touya’s foot, scowling. “You need to fix that.”

Aizawa admits he is stunned hours later when there’s a knock at his door and on the other side stands both Todoroki Natsuo and Touya. Dabi has a hoodie pulled over his face to obscure his appearance and he doesn’t look ready to murder any of them. He’s oddly quiet as Natsuo speaks for them.

“I...I didn’t know where to take him,” he admits. “I know Touya’s done a lot of wrong things but if I took him to the police they’d-”

“Kid, murdering people isn’t doing a “wrong thing”,” Hizashi cuts in severely, Natsuo slumping.

“I know,” he whispers hoarsely.

Dabi is still silent and Aizawa groans, waving a hand. “In.”

Hizashi starts to protest but Aizawa just shakes his head. He also calls Naomasa and does so in front of Dabi so he knows where the lines are drawn. The villain glares at him the whole time but there’s something off about him. He knows, then, what’s happened to him. And he’s scared. Scared, because he doesn’t know what he’s said or what he’s confessed to. Dabi’s eyes then land on the array of children’s toys he and Hizashi haven’t gotten around to cleaning yet and he stops dead in his tracks.

Then:

“I need to go.”

Aizawa’s capture weapon activates then, as well as his quirk. “Don’t test me,” he growls.

“Touya,” Natsuo murmurs, or probably pleads.

Dabi relents but he looks even more unhappy than before. His hands shake in a way Aizawa recognises from years on the job: he’s itching for a smoke. Nerves will do that to you.

Hizashi won’t talk to anyone except Aizawa and Aizawa isn’t particularly in the mood to talk. Even by bringing Dabi here, Natsuo has shown his brother too much. “He can hear you,” Dabi snaps, brow pinched and by god does he look like Shouto in that instant; petulant and prideful.

“Where’s our father?” he asks, knee bouncing. “Did he…”

“Unlikely,” Naomasa replies, though he winces. “With the information and evidence we’ve compiled, it won’t look good on Endeavour. But it also doesn’t look good on us. What we did was wrong, even if for the right reasons.”

Dabi sucks in a sharp breath there and then quickly pretends he didn’t. Right. He’s probably not used to people defending him.

“Our hands are tied. There’s only one option available to us right now.”

“But Father-”

“Didn’t make him kill people.”

“No. What he did was worse.”

Natsuo breaks down there and Aizawa feels his heart break. This isn’t fair. This isn’t fair on any of them but Naomasa is right. They can’t hide this. They can’t let Dabi escape. Even Dabi seems to know; of course he knows - it’s why he’s fighting so much.

“We can try for a lesser sentence due to psychological damage,” Naomasa tries but Natsuo just shakes his head. Surprisingly, Dabi is too. Although, he explains that a second later,

“I make my own choices.”

Dabi looks away. They’re all lost in thought until Natsuo passes his phone over. “Also, Hawks sent me this. He says it’s for you.”

Dabi frowns but takes the phone. He makes an involuntary noise at whatever’s on the screen but Aizawa doesn’t even as to ask before Dabi is fumbling for the volume switch and watching with rapt attention. Aizawa recognises the voice within seconds: Touya.

“So, he’ll see me?”

“Yeah.” And there’s Hawks.

“Well, okay! Um...hi Dabi! You don’t know me but I’m Touya. Hawks says you’re mad a lot but also really sad. I’m sad too and sometimes mad. I’m sorry bad things happened to you. Dabi snaps.

“We could kill him.”

“Whoa, not like that!” Hizashi says, hands flailing. “I mean, look, Shouta and I are going to have to move anyway. If Dabi came here and attacked us and died in the ensuing fight…”
